source.raw_text:
The Plank with Weighted Drag is a full-body exercise that builds core stability (abs, obliques, lower back), shoulder strength (deltoids, traps), upper back (lats, rhomboids), arms (triceps, biceps), and glutes/legs, challenging anti-rotation and balance while you drag a weight (dumbbell/kettlebell) across your body in a plank position, moving from isometric holds to isotonic pulls. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Core: Transversus abdominis, rectus abdominis, obliques (primary stabilizers). 
• Shoulders: Deltoids, trapezius (for stability and pulling). 
• Upper Back: Lats, rhomboids (for pulling action). 
• Arms: Triceps, biceps (assisting the pull). 
• Chest: Pectorals (stabilization). 
• Lower Body: Glutes, hamstrings, quads (for hip stabilization and preventing rotation). [1, 3, 4, 5, 6]  

Movement Patterns & Benefits 

• Isometric Core Engagement: The plank itself requires constant core contraction to maintain a straight line. 
• Isotonic Pulling: The act of dragging the weight involves concentric (pulling) and eccentric (lowering) muscle contractions in the pulling arm. 
• Anti-Rotation: Your core and hips resist the urge to rotate as the weight shifts, building anti-rotational strength. 
• Stability & Coordination: Moving under load while staying stable enhances balance and control. 
• Full Body Integration: Combines isometric (static) and isotonic (dynamic) movements for a comprehensive workout. [2, 3, 7, 8, 9]  

How it Works (Movement Pattern) 

1. Start in a high plank with hands under shoulders, feet slightly wider than hip-width, and weight next to one hand. 
2. Reach under your torso with the opposite hand to grab the weight. 
3. Drag the weight across your body to the other side, keeping hips level and core tight. 
4. Place the weight down and repeat with the other arm, alternating sides. [2, 5, 10]
